title: Mum's world 'falling apart' as son, 8, diagnosed with completely terminal tumour
text:

A family's world was turned upside down when their perfectly healthy eight-year-old was diagnosed with a terminal cancer with a 0% survival rate.

On September 11 this year Victoria Morrison dropped her son Kyle off at Andrew Lanes Primary School in Cheshunt, Hertfordshire.

A few hours later she received a call from a staff member saying she had to come in and pick him up.

When Victoria arrived five minutes later she immediately knew something was seriously wrong.

"He was having a stroke," the mum explained.

"The right side of his face had dropped. The eye and the corner of his mouth was drooping. It was really noticeable."

(Image: Daily Mirror)

Victoria bundled Kyle into their car and headed straight for hospital.

The Lego fanatic was unhappy about being wrenched out of class and with all the fuss he was getting.

Victoria said: "He kept saying 'I’m fine. I don’t need to go to hospital. I want to go home.'

"He wasn't in any pain."

Doctors at the Lister Hospital near Stevenage disagreed with Kyle's diagnosis and made him stay in overnight.

The next morning he was put through an MRI scanner and by the afternoon the results were in.

"I got called into the room and got given the news that he had a tumour," Victoria explained.

"I was quite blunt. I knew it was going to be a stroke, brain tumour or blood on the brain.

"I said 'tell me now which one is it' and the doctor did."

Kyle and Victoria were raced to Addenbrooke Hospital in Cambridge where doctors carried out further tests.

(Image: PA)

What they discovered turned a traumatic day into a devastating one for the Morrison family.

Kyle had a diffuse intrinsic pontine glioma (DIPG) tumor.

While brain tumor sufferers in the UK do not have a great prognosis - with only 15% living five years after diagnosis - significantly less than one in 100 DIPG sufferers survive for five years.

Most children die within one to four months.

"It’s a brain tumour of the nervous system," explained Victoria.

"The tumor is on his brain stem. No body has ever survived it."

After the initial heart wrenching shock Victoria, who is also mum to two-year-old Tyler, began desperately looking for help.

She called hospitals all over the world hoping somebody would offer a second opinion that might save her child's life.

Nobody did.

(Image: Daily Mirror)

Now the family are tying to come to terms with Kyle's vastly shortened life expectancy, which doctors believe could be about a year.

Having done her own research, Victoria thinks it is more likely to be as little as three months.

"I’m just trying to block it out," the mum said.

"He looks completely normal. I’m trying not to get upset about it all, but I’m quite angry."

"I want to start up my own charity. I want to scream from the rooftops about this disease and that it could happen to your child."

As the terminal diagnosis hangs over the Morrisons, Victoria has snapped into practical gear.

First of all she is preparing Kyle for a gruelling bout of treatment.

(Image: Daily Mirror)

On September 23 this meant taking the young boy into hospital to be fitted with a radiotherapy mask, a process she watched from behind a screen.

"All I saw was a red light going up and down his body and him screaming with the mask on," Victoria said.

"I thought to myself 'why the hell am I putting you through this?'

"What, so I can get a few extra months with you. Is that selfish? I don't know?

"The outcome either way is 0% survival. Do I put my baby through this for a few extra months?

"Will they suddenly find a cure? All I know is he's my bloody world and it scares me that within a year's time I won't hear his voice or even build Lego with him.

"My world is literally falling apart."

On October 7 Kyle will start a course of radiotherapy.

(Image: Daily Mirror)

When that is done he will head back to school for two days a week.

The rest of the time his mum will make sure he can do whatever he wants.

To help Kyle enjoy what time he has left as much as possible a Just Giving page has been set up on his behalf.

So far more than 350 people have donated more than £9,000, making Kyle's dream of visiting Father Christmas in Lapland a reality.

description: EXCLUSIVE Kyle Morrison from Cheshunt in Hertfordshire has a tumor with a 0% survival rate
